text: In ecology, shade tolerance refers to a plant's ability to grow with low light levels. The term is also used in gardening and landscaping. Sometimes called "shade-loving" plants, they can be grown without a lot of sunshine. Most urban gardeners must find plants that will grow in partial or full shade.The following plants are known to be shade-loving: ==Shrubs== * Hetz's Japanese holly * Inkberry holly * Hemlock ==Perennial plants== * Bleeding heart and Fringed bleeding heart (Dicentra eximia) * Dutchman's breeches (Dicentra cucullaria) * Jack-in-the-pulpit (Arisaema triphyllum) * Lenten-rose (Hellebore) * Leopard plant * Virginia bluebell (Mertensia virginica), also called Virginia cowslip, lungwort oysterleaf, and Roanoke bells * Barrenwort (Epimedium), also called bishop's hat, fairy wings, horny goat weed, or yin yang huo (Chinese) ==Annual plants== * Impatiens ==Ground covers== * Spotted deadnettle * Creeping myrtle * Pachysandra * Some types of hosta * Bunchberry ==Climbing plants== * Climbing hydrangea * Boston ivy ==References== Category:Plants Category:Gardening
title: Shade-loving plants
